trans-unit.source: Create your first search solution using Azure Search
trans-unit.target: Create your first search solution using Azure Search

trans-unit.source: Create your first search solution using Azure Search
trans-unit.target: Create your first search solution using Azure Search

trans-unit.source: This sample demonstrates a search application for the Adventure Works bicycle company.
trans-unit.target: This sample demonstrates a search application for the Adventure Works bicycle company.

trans-unit.source: After completing this tutorial, you’ll have an online product catalog with a rich search experience that includes faceted navigation, multiple sort options for your search results, and type-ahead query suggestions.
trans-unit.target: After completing this tutorial, you’ll have an online product catalog with a rich search experience that includes faceted navigation, multiple sort options for your search results, and type-ahead query suggestions.

trans-unit.source: The demo gets you started with Azure Search by walking you through these exercises:
trans-unit.target: The demo gets you started with Azure Search by walking you through these exercises:

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure Search index.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure Search index.

trans-unit.source: Load documents (data) into the Azure Search index from a SQL Server database.
trans-unit.target: Load documents (data) into the Azure Search index from a SQL Server database.

trans-unit.source: Build an ASP.NET MVC4 Application that utilizes Azure Search to:
trans-unit.target: Build an ASP.NET MVC4 Application that utilizes Azure Search to:

trans-unit.source: Search and display results from an Azure Search index
trans-unit.target: Search and display results from an Azure Search index

trans-unit.source: Show type-ahead suggestions in a Search box while entering a search term
trans-unit.target: Show type-ahead suggestions in a Search box while entering a search term

trans-unit.source: Filter search results using faceting
trans-unit.target: Filter search results using faceting

trans-unit.source: An <linkText>Azure subscription</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: An <linkText>Azure subscription</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If you aren't ready to sign up for a trial subscription, you can skip this tutorial and opt for <linkText>Try Azure App Service</linkText><title></title> instead.
trans-unit.target: If you aren't ready to sign up for a trial subscription, you can skip this tutorial and opt for <linkText>Try Azure App Service</linkText><title></title> instead.

trans-unit.source: This alternative option gives you Azure Search with an ASP.NET Web app for free - one hour per session - no subscription required.
trans-unit.target: This alternative option gives you Azure Search with an ASP.NET Web app for free - one hour per session - no subscription required.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2012 or higher with ASP.NET MVC 4 and SQL Server installed.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2012 or higher with ASP.NET MVC 4 and SQL Server installed.

trans-unit.source: You can download the free Express editions if you don't already have the software installed: <linkText>Visual Studio 2013 Express</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Microsoft SQL Server 2014 Express</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can download the free Express editions if you don't already have the software installed: <linkText>Visual Studio 2013 Express</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Microsoft SQL Server 2014 Express</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: An Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: An Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: You'll need the Search service name, plus the admin key.
trans-unit.target: You'll need the Search service name, plus the admin key.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Create an Azure Search service in the portal</linkText><title></title> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Create an Azure Search service in the portal</linkText><title></title> for details.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Adventure Works Azure Search Demo project on CodePlex</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Adventure Works Azure Search Demo project on CodePlex</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: On the Source tab, click Download to get a zip file of the solution.
trans-unit.target: On the Source tab, click Download to get a zip file of the solution.

trans-unit.source: This solution contains two projects:
trans-unit.target: This solution contains two projects:

trans-unit.source: CatalogIndex creates an Azure Search index and loads data from a SQL Server database included with the project.
trans-unit.target: CatalogIndex creates an Azure Search index and loads data from a SQL Server database included with the project.

trans-unit.source: AdventureWorksWeb is an MVC4-based application that queries the Azure Search index.
trans-unit.target: AdventureWorksWeb is an MVC4-based application that queries the Azure Search index.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes that you have a working knowledge of ASP.NET MVC.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes that you have a working knowledge of ASP.NET MVC.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will use CatalogIndex to create a new Azure Search index called "catalog" based on data in an AdventureWorks SQL Server database.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will use CatalogIndex to create a new Azure Search index called "catalog" based on data in an AdventureWorks SQL Server database.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open up the Azure Search Demo solution named AdventureWorksCatalog.sln.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open up the Azure Search Demo solution named AdventureWorksCatalog.sln.

trans-unit.source: Right-click CatalogIndexer in Solution Explorer and select Set as startup project so that this application runs, rather than the AdventureWorksWeb project, when you press F5.
trans-unit.target: Right-click CatalogIndexer in Solution Explorer and select Set as startup project so that this application runs, rather than the AdventureWorksWeb project, when you press F5.

trans-unit.source: Open App.config in this project and update the values for "SearchServiceName" and "SearchServiceApiKey" to those of your Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: Open App.config in this project and update the values for "SearchServiceName" and "SearchServiceApiKey" to those of your Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: For Search service name, if your service is "mysearch.search.windows.net", you would enter "mysearch".
trans-unit.target: For Search service name, if your service is "mysearch.search.windows.net", you would enter "mysearch".

trans-unit.source: Optionally, App.config includes an entry for "SourceSqlConnectionString" that assumes SQL Server 2014 Express LocalDB (Server=(LocalDB)\v11.0).
trans-unit.target: Optionally, App.config includes an entry for "SourceSqlConnectionString" that assumes SQL Server 2014 Express LocalDB (Server=(LocalDB)\v11.0).

trans-unit.source: If you’re using a different edition of SQL Server, update the server name accordingly.
trans-unit.target: If you’re using a different edition of SQL Server, update the server name accordingly.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you have a local default instance, you can use (local) or localhost.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you have a local default instance, you can use (local) or localhost.

trans-unit.source: Save App.config.
trans-unit.target: Save App.config.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to launch the project.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to launch the project.

trans-unit.source: A command prompt should open with the following text: "Creating index..."
trans-unit.target: A command prompt should open with the following text: "Creating index..."

trans-unit.source: After a few moments, it should complete with the text: "Complete. Press <enter> to continue:"
trans-unit.target: After a few moments, it should complete with the text: "Complete. Press <enter> to continue:"

trans-unit.source: Press Enter to close the application.
trans-unit.target: Press Enter to close the application.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have successfully created the Azure Search index.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have successfully created the Azure Search index.

trans-unit.source: If you get errors that include "invalid value for key 'attachdbfilename'" or some other database attachment error, you might be running into UAC conflicts.
trans-unit.target: If you get errors that include "invalid value for key 'attachdbfilename'" or some other database attachment error, you might be running into UAC conflicts.

trans-unit.source: For the purposes of this demo, work around these errors by doing the following: Copy the solution to a new or existing folder (such as Temp) that provides access to authenticated users.
trans-unit.target: For the purposes of this demo, work around these errors by doing the following: Copy the solution to a new or existing folder (such as Temp) that provides access to authenticated users.

trans-unit.source: Use Run as Administrator to start Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Use Run as Administrator to start Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Open the solution, build it, and then press F5 to create the index.
trans-unit.target: Open the solution, build it, and then press F5 to create the index.

trans-unit.source: To verify index creation and document upload, go to your Search service dashboard in the <linkText>Azure management portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To verify index creation and document upload, go to your Search service dashboard in the <linkText>Azure management portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In Usage, the index count should be up by one, and you should have 294 documents, one for each product in the database.
trans-unit.target: In Usage, the index count should be up by one, and you should have 294 documents, one for each product in the database.

trans-unit.source: Click the Indexes tile to show the index list.
trans-unit.target: Click the Indexes tile to show the index list.

trans-unit.source: The indexes list slides out to show the new index and document count.
trans-unit.target: The indexes list slides out to show the new index and document count.

trans-unit.source: Note that you can have up to three indexes at the Free pricing tier.
trans-unit.target: Note that you can have up to three indexes at the Free pricing tier.

trans-unit.source: If you already had three indexes, you would need to delete one to free up space for any new ones.
trans-unit.target: If you already had three indexes, you would need to delete one to free up space for any new ones.

trans-unit.source: Let’s take a closer look at the CatalogIndexer project to understand how it works.
trans-unit.target: Let’s take a closer look at the CatalogIndexer project to understand how it works.

trans-unit.source: Open Program.cs from the Solution Explorer and go to the Main(string[] args) function.
trans-unit.target: Open Program.cs from the Solution Explorer and go to the Main(string[] args) function.

trans-unit.source: Notice how this function builds up a Uri called _serviceURI based on your specific Azure Search service and then creates an HttpClient called _httpClient that makes use of your API Key to authenticate to this Search service.
trans-unit.target: Notice how this function builds up a Uri called _serviceURI based on your specific Azure Search service and then creates an HttpClient called _httpClient that makes use of your API Key to authenticate to this Search service.

trans-unit.source: ChangeEnumeratorSql and ChangeSet are used to enumerate the data from the Products table in your SQL Server AdventureWorks database.
trans-unit.target: ChangeEnumeratorSql and ChangeSet are used to enumerate the data from the Products table in your SQL Server AdventureWorks database.

trans-unit.source: Based on the data that is collected from this table, ApplyChanges is then called to apply this data to your Azure Search index.
trans-unit.target: Based on the data that is collected from this table, ApplyChanges is then called to apply this data to your Azure Search index.

trans-unit.source: Move to ApplyChanges in the same file.
trans-unit.target: Move to ApplyChanges in the same file.

trans-unit.source: Notice how this function deletes the index if it already exists (DeleteCatalogIndex) and then creates a new index called "catalog" (CreateCatalogIndex).
trans-unit.target: Notice how this function deletes the index if it already exists (DeleteCatalogIndex) and then creates a new index called "catalog" (CreateCatalogIndex).

trans-unit.source: Move to the CreateCatalogIndex function, and notice how the index is created with a schema that matches the columns from the Products table in SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: Move to the CreateCatalogIndex function, and notice how the index is created with a schema that matches the columns from the Products table in SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: Each field has a Type (i.e., Edm.String or Edm.Double) as well as attributes that define what these fields are used for.
trans-unit.target: Each field has a Type (i.e., Edm.String or Edm.Double) as well as attributes that define what these fields are used for.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the <linkText>Azure Search REST API documentation</linkText><title></title> for more details on these attributes.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the <linkText>Azure Search REST API documentation</linkText><title></title> for more details on these attributes.

trans-unit.source: Go back to the ApplyChanges function.
trans-unit.target: Go back to the ApplyChanges function.

trans-unit.source: Notice how this function loops through all of the data in the enumerated changes ChangeSet.
trans-unit.target: Notice how this function loops through all of the data in the enumerated changes ChangeSet.

trans-unit.source: Rather than applying the changes one by one, they are batched into groups of 1000 and then applied to the Search service.
trans-unit.target: Rather than applying the changes one by one, they are batched into groups of 1000 and then applied to the Search service.

trans-unit.source: This is much more efficient than applying the documents one by one.
trans-unit.target: This is much more efficient than applying the documents one by one.

trans-unit.source: Now that you've seen how to create and populate an index using relational data from SQL Server, let’s take a look at how to build a product catalog that uses our search data.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've seen how to create and populate an index using relational data from SQL Server, let’s take a look at how to build a product catalog that uses our search data.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you’ll build and run the search application in a web browser.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you’ll build and run the search application in a web browser.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open up the Azure Search Demo Solution named AdventureWorksCatalog.sln.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open up the Azure Search Demo Solution named AdventureWorksCatalog.sln.

trans-unit.source: Right-click AdventureWorksWeb in the Solution Explorer and select Set as startup project.
trans-unit.target: Right-click AdventureWorksWeb in the Solution Explorer and select Set as startup project.

trans-unit.source: Open Web.config in this project and update the values for "SearchServiceName" and "SearchServiceApiKey" to those of your Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: Open Web.config in this project and update the values for "SearchServiceName" and "SearchServiceApiKey" to those of your Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: For Search service name, if your service is "mysearch.search.windows.net", you would enter "mysearch".
trans-unit.target: For Search service name, if your service is "mysearch.search.windows.net", you would enter "mysearch".

trans-unit.source: Save Web.config.
trans-unit.target: Save Web.config.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to launch the project.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to launch the project.

trans-unit.source: Follow these <linkText>Troubleshooting</linkText><title></title> steps if you get a build error.
trans-unit.target: Follow these <linkText>Troubleshooting</linkText><title></title> steps if you get a build error.

trans-unit.source: Leave the search box empty, and click Search to return all 294 products.
trans-unit.target: Leave the search box empty, and click Search to return all 294 products.

trans-unit.source: Notice the list of facets along on the left side.
trans-unit.target: Notice the list of facets along on the left side.

trans-unit.source: Try clicking one of the facets.
trans-unit.target: Try clicking one of the facets.

trans-unit.source: Search is re-executed, but this time it adds the facet you chose to filter the results.
trans-unit.target: Search is re-executed, but this time it adds the facet you chose to filter the results.

trans-unit.source: You may want to add a breakpoint to the first line in the HomeController.cs Search function to step through (F11) each line.
trans-unit.target: You may want to add a breakpoint to the first line in the HomeController.cs Search function to step through (F11) each line.

trans-unit.source: Enter a search term, such as "mountain bikes".
trans-unit.target: Enter a search term, such as "mountain bikes".

trans-unit.source: As you type, notice the drop-down list of suggested queries.
trans-unit.target: As you type, notice the drop-down list of suggested queries.

trans-unit.source: The screenshot from the start of this demo appears again below, as a reminder of what was covered.
trans-unit.target: The screenshot from the start of this demo appears again below, as a reminder of what was covered.

trans-unit.source: In the previous sections, we discussed faceted navigation (on the left), the document count at the top of the page, suggestions, and the sort options for sorting by relevance, list, or price.
trans-unit.target: In the previous sections, we discussed faceted navigation (on the left), the document count at the top of the page, suggestions, and the sort options for sorting by relevance, list, or price.

trans-unit.source: The project AdventureWorksWeb shows us how ASP.NET MVC 4 can be used to interact with Azure Search from a web application.
trans-unit.target: The project AdventureWorksWeb shows us how ASP.NET MVC 4 can be used to interact with Azure Search from a web application.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we’ll review individual parts of the application code to see what they do.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we’ll review individual parts of the application code to see what they do.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, expand AdventureWorksWeb | Controller and open HomeController.cs
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, expand AdventureWorksWeb | Controller and open HomeController.cs

trans-unit.source: This is the MVC controller that manages the interaction from the Index view.
trans-unit.target: This is the MVC controller that manages the interaction from the Index view.

trans-unit.source: At the top of the controller, you will notice a reference to CatalogSearch _catalogSearch which creates a HttpClient connection object to your Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: At the top of the controller, you will notice a reference to CatalogSearch _catalogSearch which creates a HttpClient connection object to your Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: The code for this CatalogSearch is located in CatalogSeach.cs
trans-unit.target: The code for this CatalogSearch is located in CatalogSeach.cs

trans-unit.source: Within HomeController.cs, there are two main functions:
trans-unit.target: Within HomeController.cs, there are two main functions:

trans-unit.source: Search: When the user clicks on the search button or chooses a facet, this function is called to retrieve the results and send them back to the Index view to be displayed.
trans-unit.target: Search: When the user clicks on the search button or chooses a facet, this function is called to retrieve the results and send them back to the Index view to be displayed.

trans-unit.source: Suggest: As the user is typing in the Search box, this function is called to return a list of suggestions based on the content in your Azure Search index.
trans-unit.target: Suggest: As the user is typing in the Search box, this function is called to return a list of suggestions based on the content in your Azure Search index.

trans-unit.source: Let’s drill into these two functions in more detail.
trans-unit.target: Let’s drill into these two functions in more detail.

trans-unit.source: In HomeController.cs Search function, you will notice a call to _catalogSearch.Search, which includes the connection object to your Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: In HomeController.cs Search function, you will notice a call to _catalogSearch.Search, which includes the connection object to your Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: When you call the Search function located in CatalogSearch.cs, you can see that it utilizes these parameters to build out an Azure Search query.
trans-unit.target: When you call the Search function located in CatalogSearch.cs, you can see that it utilizes these parameters to build out an Azure Search query.

trans-unit.source: The results of the query are stored in a JSON object called result and then passed back to the Index view where the results are parsed and displayed in the web page.
trans-unit.target: The results of the query are stored in a JSON object called result and then passed back to the Index view where the results are parsed and displayed in the web page.

trans-unit.source: Open Index.cshtml under Views | Home, you will notice the code that is used to parse these results.
trans-unit.target: Open Index.cshtml under Views | Home, you will notice the code that is used to parse these results.

trans-unit.source: Stop the application if it’s still running, and open Index.cshtml file under Views | Home.
trans-unit.target: Stop the application if it’s still running, and open Index.cshtml file under Views | Home.

trans-unit.source: At the end of this file, you will see a JavaScript function that uses JQuery $(function ()).
trans-unit.target: At the end of this file, you will see a JavaScript function that uses JQuery $(function ()).

trans-unit.source: This function is called when the page loads.
trans-unit.target: This function is called when the page loads.

trans-unit.source: It uses the JQuery autocomplete function and links this function as a callback from the search text box, identified as "q".
trans-unit.target: It uses the JQuery autocomplete function and links this function as a callback from the search text box, identified as "q".

trans-unit.source: Whenever someone types into the text box, this autosuggest function is called which in turn calls /home/suggest with what is entered.
trans-unit.target: Whenever someone types into the text box, this autosuggest function is called which in turn calls /home/suggest with what is entered.

trans-unit.source: /home/suggest is a reference to the function in HomeController.cs called Suggest.
trans-unit.target: /home/suggest is a reference to the function in HomeController.cs called Suggest.

trans-unit.source: Open HomeController.cs and move to the Suggest function.
trans-unit.target: Open HomeController.cs and move to the Suggest function.

trans-unit.source: This code is very similar to the Search function that uses the _catalogSearch object to call a function in CatalogSearch.cs called Suggest.
trans-unit.target: This code is very similar to the Search function that uses the _catalogSearch object to call a function in CatalogSearch.cs called Suggest.

trans-unit.source: Rather than making a search query, the Suggest function makes a call to the Suggestions API.
trans-unit.target: Rather than making a search query, the Suggest function makes a call to the Suggestions API.

trans-unit.source: This uses the terms entered in the text box and build out a list of potential suggestions.
trans-unit.target: This uses the terms entered in the text box and build out a list of potential suggestions.

trans-unit.source: The values are returned to the Index.cshtml file that are automatically listed in the Search box as type-ahead options.
trans-unit.target: The values are returned to the Index.cshtml file that are automatically listed in the Search box as type-ahead options.

trans-unit.source: You might be asking yourself at this point how Azure Search knows what fields to build suggestions over.
trans-unit.target: You might be asking yourself at this point how Azure Search knows what fields to build suggestions over.

trans-unit.source: The answer to this is back when you created the Index.
trans-unit.target: The answer to this is back when you created the Index.

trans-unit.source: In the CreateCatalogIndex function within the file Program.cs of the CatalogIndexer project, there is an attribute called Suggestions.
trans-unit.target: In the CreateCatalogIndex function within the file Program.cs of the CatalogIndexer project, there is an attribute called Suggestions.

trans-unit.source: Whenever this attribute is set to True, it means that Azure Search can use it as a field for retrieving suggestions
trans-unit.target: Whenever this attribute is set to True, it means that Azure Search can use it as a field for retrieving suggestions

trans-unit.source: Let’s give this a try.
trans-unit.target: Let’s give this a try.

trans-unit.source: Once again, build the application and then press F5 to run the application.
trans-unit.target: Once again, build the application and then press F5 to run the application.

trans-unit.source: In the search box type in the word "Road".
trans-unit.target: In the search box type in the word "Road".

trans-unit.source: After a second, you should see a list of items display below the text box with Suggestions that a user could potentially choose.
trans-unit.target: After a second, you should see a list of items display below the text box with Suggestions that a user could potentially choose.

trans-unit.source: You might want to add a breakpoint to the Suggest function within HomeController.cs and step through (F11) each call that is made to build out the Suggestion list.
trans-unit.target: You might want to add a breakpoint to the Suggest function within HomeController.cs and step through (F11) each call that is made to build out the Suggestion list.

trans-unit.source: This concludes the demo.
trans-unit.target: This concludes the demo.

trans-unit.source: You have now walked through all of the main operations that you'll need to know before building out an ASP.NET MVC4 application using Azure Search.
trans-unit.target: You have now walked through all of the main operations that you'll need to know before building out an ASP.NET MVC4 application using Azure Search.

trans-unit.source: When building AdventureWorksWeb, if you get "Could not load file or assembly 'System.Web.Mvc, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35' or one of its dependencies", try these steps to resolve the error.
trans-unit.target: When building AdventureWorksWeb, if you get "Could not load file or assembly 'System.Web.Mvc, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35' or one of its dependencies", try these steps to resolve the error.

trans-unit.source: Open the Package Manager Console: Tools | NuGet Package Manager | Package Manager Console
trans-unit.target: Open the Package Manager Console: Tools | NuGet Package Manager | Package Manager Console

trans-unit.source: At the PM> prompt, enter "Update-package -reinstall Microsoft.AspNet.Mvc"
trans-unit.target: At the PM> prompt, enter "Update-package -reinstall Microsoft.AspNet.Mvc"

trans-unit.source: When asked to reload the file, choose Yes to All.
trans-unit.target: When asked to reload the file, choose Yes to All.

trans-unit.source: Rebuild the solution and try F5 again.
trans-unit.target: Rebuild the solution and try F5 again.

trans-unit.source: For additional self-study, consider adding a Details page that opens when a user clicks one of the Search results.
trans-unit.target: For additional self-study, consider adding a Details page that opens when a user clicks one of the Search results.

trans-unit.source: To prepare, you could do the following:
trans-unit.target: To prepare, you could do the following:

trans-unit.source: Read up on the <linkText>Lookup API</linkText><title></title> that allows you to make a query to Azure Search to bring back a specific document (for example you could pass the productID).
trans-unit.target: Read up on the <linkText>Lookup API</linkText><title></title> that allows you to make a query to Azure Search to bring back a specific document (for example you could pass the productID).

trans-unit.source: Try adding a new function in the HomeController.cs file called Details.
trans-unit.target: Try adding a new function in the HomeController.cs file called Details.

trans-unit.source: Add a corresponding Details.cshtml view that receives the results of this Lookup and displays the results.
trans-unit.target: Add a corresponding Details.cshtml view that receives the results of this Lookup and displays the results.

trans-unit.source: Check out this additional code sample and video on geospatial search: <linkText>Channel 9 - Azure Search and Geospatial Data</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>CodePlex: Azure Search GeoSearch Sample</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: Check out this additional code sample and video on geospatial search: <linkText>Channel 9 - Azure Search and Geospatial Data</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>CodePlex: Azure Search GeoSearch Sample</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: You can also review the <linkText>Azure Search REST API</linkText><title></title> on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: You can also review the <linkText>Azure Search REST API</linkText><title></title> on MSDN.
